questionList.questionText: A 2-hour-old boy is in the newborn nursery with tachycardia.  The patient was born at 40 weeks gestation to a 30-year-old woman with Graves disease that was previously treated with surgical resection.  Weight is 2.08 kg (4 lb 9 oz) (<5th percentile).  Temperature is 37.2 C (99 F) and pulse is 190/min.  Examination shows an irritable but consolable infant with warm, flushed skin.  Appropriate pharmacotherapy is initiated.  Which of the following is the most likely course of this patient's condition?
questionList.explanationText:
Neonatal Graves disease

Pathophysiology

  • Transplacental passage of maternal TSH receptor–stimulating antibodies (due to maternal Graves disease)
  • Antibodies bind to infant's TSH receptors & cause excessive thyroid hormone release → neonatal thyrotoxicosis

Clinical features

  • Tachycardia & irritability
  • Warm, moist skin
  • Low birth weight or preterm birth
  • ± Goiter, stare

Diagnosis

  • Maternal & neonatal TSH receptor–stimulating antibodies
  • ↓ TSH, ↑ free thyroxine

Treatment & outcome

  • Methimazole plus β blocker
  • Usually self-resolves within months (due to clearance of maternal antibodies)

This neonate with a maternal history of Graves disease has low birth weight, tachycardia, and irritability.  These findings are consistent with neonatal Graves disease (thyrotoxicosis) due to transplacental passage of maternal TSH receptor–stimulating antibodies.  The antibodies bind fetal TSH receptors and cause excessive thyroid hormone release.  Although neonates born to women with active Graves disease during pregnancy are at greatest risk, elevated maternal antibody levels can occur despite prior treatment (eg, thyroidectomy) and lead to neonatal disease.

Presentation can occur at birth or within the first few weeks of life and commonly includes tachycardia with bounding pulses, irritability, and warm/moist skin, as seen in this patient.  Prematurity and/or low birth weight with reduced subcutaneous fat is common, and microcephaly and craniosynostosis can occur.  Neonatal goiter or staring gaze may be present, and these more specific findings often raise suspicion in infants born to mothers with unrecognized Graves disease.

Management includes short-term treatment with methimazole plus a beta blocker to prevent adverse effects of neonatal hyperthyroidism on the developing nervous system (eg, developmental/behavioral problems, poor growth).  However, these medications can typically be rapidly tapered and discontinued because neonatal Graves disease usually self-resolves over weeks to months as maternal antibodies are metabolized and cleared from the infant's circulation (Choice C).

(Choice A)  Infants with congenital hypothyroidism have a lifelong deficiency of thyroid hormone and require levothyroxine supplementation.  Unlike this neonate, patients are asymptomatic in the immediate newborn period, and symptoms that develop over weeks to months include lethargy, poor feeding, and prolonged jaundice.  This newborn has signs of hyperthyroidism (eg, tachycardia, irritability, flushed skin).

(Choices B and D)  Radioactive iodine therapy and thyroidectomy are treatment options for Graves disease due to the production and secretion of thyroid autoantibodies (ie, in older children and adults).  Because neonatal Graves disease is due to transplacental antibody transfer, the condition self-resolves and does not require ablation or gland removal.

Educational objective:
Infants born to women with Graves disease are at risk for neonatal Graves disease due to the transplacental transfer of TSH receptor–stimulating antibodies.  Manifestations (eg, tachycardia, irritability, flushed skin) are treated short term with antithyroid medication and beta blockers, and the condition spontaneously resolves within weeks to months due to the disappearance of maternal antibodies.
questionList.subject: Obstetrics & Gynecology
questionList.title: Hyperthyroidism

answerChoiceList.choice: Progressive symptoms until radioactive iodine therapy
Resolution of symptoms after thyroid gland removal

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Management of neonates born to mothers with Graves' disease.

questionList.questionText:
A 58-year-old man comes to the physician with a one-year history of diarrhea.  The stools are watery and accompanied by abdominal cramps.  He has no fever, blood from the rectum, or foul-smelling stools.  He has also experienced frequent episodes of dizziness, flushing, wheezing, and a feeling of warmth.  The patient has taken herbal medicines, which failed to relieve his symptoms.  He is depressed about his illness and feels hopeless about diagnosis and treatment.  He appears ill.  Cardiac auscultation shows a 2/6 systolic murmur over the left lower sternal border that increases with inspiration.  Abdominal examination shows hepatomegaly 3 cm below the right costal margin and no abdominal tenderness.  Laboratory results are as follows:

Hemoglobin14.0 g/dL
Mean corpuscular volume90 fL
Platelets200,000/µL
Leukocytes6,100/µL
Alkaline phosphatase400 U/L
Aspartate aminotransferase (SGOT)101 U/L
Alanine aminotransferase (SGPT)99 U/L

This patient is at risk of developing a deficiency of which of the following vitamins or minerals?
questionList.explanationText:
Features of carcinoid syndrome

Clinical manifestations

  • Skin: flushing, telangiectasias, cyanosis
  • Gastrointestinal: diarrhea, cramping
  • Cardiac: valvular lesions (right > left side)
  • Pulmonary: bronchospasm
  • Miscellaneous: niacin deficiency (dermatitis, diarrhea, dementia)

Diagnosis

  • Elevated 24-hr urinary excretion of 5-HIAA
  • CT scan/MRI of abdomen & pelvis to localize tumor
  • OctreoScan to detect metastases
  • Echocardiogram (if symptoms of carcinoid heart disease are present)

Treatment

  • Octreotide for symptomatic patients & prior to surgery/anesthesia
  • Surgery for liver metastases

The patient's clinical features - episodic flushing and wheezing, diarrhea, and valvular heart disease with tricuspid regurgitation - are consistent with carcinoid syndrome.  Carcinoids are slow-growing tumors found most commonly in the distal small intestine, proximal colon, and lung.  These tumors can secrete several products, including histamine, serotonin, and vasoactive intestinal peptide, that are metabolized in the liver.  Gastrointestinal carcinoid tumors often metastasize to the liver.  In such cases, the liver is unable to metabolize these hormones before they are released into the systemic circulation, leading to the carcinoid syndrome.  Other clinical features include cutaneous telangiectasias and tricuspid regurgitation.

Serotonin is synthesized in carcinoid cells from tryptophan, which is also used in the production of niacin or nicotinic acid.  Advanced disease results in increased tryptophan conversion to serotonin and its metabolite 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid.  This may result in tryptophan and niacin deficiency causing pellagra (with diarrhea, dermatitis, glossitis, angular stomatitis, and dementia).

(Choices A and E)  Neither calcium nor vitamin C deficiency is associated with carcinoid syndrome.

(Choice B)  Iron deficiency is typically not seen in patients with carcinoid syndrome.  In addition, this patient's serum hemoglobin and mean corpuscular volume are within normal limits, making iron deficiency even less likely.

(Choice D)  Vitamin A deficiency is not seen in association with carcinoid syndrome.  It occurs most commonly due to dietary deficiency or in association with fat malabsorption (eg, celiac disease, small-bowel Crohn's disease, pancreatic insufficiency).  Fatty diarrhea or steatorrhea typically causes pale, greasy, and malodorous stools, unlike the watery diarrhea seen in patients with carcinoid syndrome.

Educational objective:
Carcinoid tumors are rare neuroendocrine tumors that cause episodic flushing, secretory diarrhea, bronchospasm, and cardiac valvular abnormalities.  Carcinoid cells cause increased production of serotonin from tryptophan (required for niacin synthesis), resulting in niacin deficiency (ie, pellagra, with dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia).
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Carcinoid tumors

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Carcinoid syndrome and well-differentiated neuroendocrine tumors
Carcinoid syndrome: diagnosis and medical management.

questionList.questionText:
A 30-year-old Hispanic male presents to the office with complaints of palpitations, tremor, nervousness and headache.  His past history is insignificant.  His mother has type 2 diabetes, which is well-controlled with medications.  His temperature is 37.0° C (98.6° F), pulse is 100/min, blood pressure is 150/80 mm Hg, and respirations are 16/min.  He appears anxious, sweaty and shaky.  His neurological examination is non-focal, and examination of other systems is unremarkable.  His fingerstick blood glucose level is 38 mg/dL.  Intravenous administration of a bolus of 50% dextrose leads to the improvement of his symptoms.  He is then subjected to supervised prolonged fasting.  After an overnight fast, laboratory studies reveal:

Blood glucose40 mg/dL
Serum insulin15 microU/L (normal value is < 6 microU/L with hypoglycemia)
Serum pro-insulin9 microU/L (normal value is < 20% of total immunoreactive insulin)
C-peptide level0.8 nmol/L   (normal value is less than 0.2 nmol/L)
SulfonylureaNegative
IGF-IINegative

Based on the above information, what is the most likely cause of this patient's hypoglycemia?
questionList.explanationText:
In normal individuals, a blood glucose level below 60 mg/dL results in near-complete suppression of insulin secretion.  The patient in this vignette thus presents with hypoglycemia and inappropriately elevated serum insulin levels. 

There are two important causes of hypoglycemia in non-diabetic patients with elevated insulin levels:  

  1. insulinoma (beta cell tumor)
  2. surreptitious use of insulin or sulfonylurea 

Elevated C-peptide levels and proinsulin levels greater than 5 pmol/L are seen in patients with beta cell tumors; therefore, this is the most likely diagnosis.

(Choice B) Non-beta cell tumors, typically large mesenchymal tumors, can lead to hypoglycemia independent of insulin.  Such tumors produce insulin-like growth factor II (IGF II), which has an insulinomimetic action after binding to insulin receptors.  In patients with suspected non-beta cell tumors, the serum IGF II level can be measured.  Patients with this condition characteristically have suppressed insulin and c-peptide levels.

(Choice C) Sulfonylurea causes an increased output of endogenous insulin from the beta cells.  Patients with sulfonylurea-induced hypoglycemia are sometimes difficult to differentiate from those with insulinoma because increased insulin and c-peptide levels are seen in both groups.  Nonetheless, the proinsulin level is sometimes lower than 20% of the total insulin immunoreactivity.  The diagnosis is confirmed by measuring the plasma sulfonylurea level.

(Choice D) Exogenous insulin-induced hypoglycemia is associated with very high serum insulin levels combined with low c-peptide levels.  The low c-peptide levels result from the suppression of endogenous insulin production. 

(Choice E) Glucagonoma produces a characteristic skin rash (necrotic migratory erythema) with elevated blood glucose levels (not hypoglycemia).

Educational Objective:
Hypoglycemia is associated with multiple differential diagnoses.  Helpful tests used in the evaluation of hypoglycemic patients are measurements of c-peptide, proinsulin and sulfonylurea levels.  Hypoglycemia secondary to insulinoma is associated with elevated insulin, c-peptide and proinsulin levels.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Hypoglycemia

questionList.questionText: A 64-year-old woman comes to the office due to a progressive rash.  The patient initially had painful, itchy red spots on her right leg 2 months ago, which gradually enlarged and began to crust.  Similar spots later appeared on her abdomen and chin.  She has used several over-the-counter corticosteroid and antibiotic creams with no improvement.  The patient has had no palpitations, abdominal pain, or vomiting, but has had occasional watery stools.  She was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus 6 months ago, and lifestyle modification was advised.  The patient does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs.  Temperature is 37 C (98.6 F), blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg, pulse is 78/min, and respirations are 14/min.  Weight is 10 kg (22 lb) lower than 6 months ago; BMI is 21 kg/m2.  Physical examination shows erythematous plaques with central clearing and eroded borders on the right thigh.  There are scattered papules with crusting over the lower abdomen and in the perioral skin.  The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities.  Laboratory studies are significant for a hemoglobin level of 10.2 g/dL and glucose level of 176 mg/dL.  Which of the following would be most helpful in establishing the diagnosis in this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Features of glucagonoma

Clinical presentation

  • Weight loss
  • Necrolytic migratory erythema: erythematous papules that coalesce to form large, indurated plaques with central clearing
  • Diabetes mellitus/hyperglycemia
  • Gastrointestinal symptoms (eg, diarrhea, anorexia, abdominal pain)

Diagnosis

  • Markedly elevated glucagon level
  • Abdominal imaging (MRI or CT scan)

This patient with diabetes mellitus, weight loss, diarrhea, and a painful, pruritic rash likely has a glucagonoma, a pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor characterized by the unregulated release of glucagon.  Manifestations reflect the effects of glucagon, which increases amino acid oxidation and has catabolic actions.

Glucagonoma is often diagnosed late in the disease course due to nonspecific early features; necrolytic migratory erythema (NME) is the presenting feature in ~70% of patients.  NME, likely due to amino acid deficiency, is characterized by painful/pruritic papules that coalesce to form large, indurated plaques with scaling and central clearing on the face, groin, and extremities.  The excess glucagon also causes hyperglycemia/diabetes mellitus, although this is usually mild and rarely requires insulin.  Other common features include weight loss (catabolic action of glucagon), diarrhea (secretion of glucagon and other molecules [eg, secretin]), venous thromboembolism, and neuropsychiatric symptoms (eg, depression, psychosis).

Laboratory evaluation typically shows normocytic, normochromic anemia, which may be due to anemia of chronic disease or a direct effect of glucagon on erythropoiesis.  A markedly elevated serum glucagon level (>500 pg/mL) confirms the diagnosis.  Although glucagon is increased in other conditions (eg, hypoglycemia, Cushing syndrome, pancreatitis), the elevations are typically mild to moderate.  Abdominal imaging (CT scan or MRI) can localize the tumor and evaluate for metastases.

(Choice A)  Antimitochondrial antibodies are associated with primary biliary cholangitis, which presents with diffuse pruritis, jaundice, hepatomegaly, and abnormal liver markers (eg, alkaline phosphatase, aminotransferases).  Skin manifestations include xanthomas and hyperpigmentation.

(Choice C)  Porphyria cutanea tarda causes skin fragility and chronic, scarring blisters and bullae in sun-exposed areas.  It is commonly associated with hepatitis C; hepatic aminotransferases are often mildly elevated.  Blood counts are typically normal.

(Choice D)  Vitamin A deficiency most commonly presents with impaired night vision.  Skin findings (eg, hyperkeratosis) are usually nonspecific.

(Choice E)  Tissue transglutaminase IgA antibodies are seen in dermatitis herpetiformis, typically associated with celiac disease.  Skin manifestations include grouped, intensely pruritic papules and vesicles on the extensor surfaces of the elbows, knees, back, and buttocks.

(Choice F)  Niacin deficiency is characterized by photosensitive, pigmented dermatitis (primarily in sun-exposed areas); diarrhea; and neuropsychiatric symptoms (eg, dementia, psychosis).

Educational objective:
Glucagonomas frequently cause necrolytic migratory erythema, characterized by painful/pruritic papules that coalesce to form large plaques on the face, groin, and extremities.  Other manifestations include diabetes mellitus, weight loss, diarrhea, and anemia.  A serum glucagon level >500 pg/mL confirms the diagnosis, and abdominal imaging can localize the tumor and evaluate for metastases.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Glucagonoma

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Glucagonoma syndrome: a review and update on treatment.

questionList.questionText:
A 75-year-old woman comes to the office due to 2 months of heat intolerance, sweating, and palpitation.  The patient has lost significant weight recently despite increasing her food intake.  Medical history is notable for hypertension and heart failure with preserved ejection fraction.  Temperature is 37.2 C (99 F), blood pressure is 146/80 mm Hg, pulse is 116/min and regular, and respirations are 18/min.  Physical examination shows a mildly enlarged and nontender thyroid.  There is no proptosis or pretibial myxedema.  Laboratory results are as follows:

Leukocytesnormal
Serum creatinine1.0 mg/dL
TSH<0.001 µU/mL
T3500 ng/dL
Free thyroxine (T4)4.7 ng/dL (normal: 0.9-1.7 ng/dL)

Radioactive iodine uptake at 24 hours is significantly increased and homogeneously distributed throughout the thyroid gland.  Atenolol is prescribed to control the patient's symptoms and tachycardia.  Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient's thyroid disorder?
questionList.explanationText:
Treatment of Graves disease

β-Blockers

  • Initiated at diagnosis to mitigate hyperadrenergic complications

Antithyroid
drugs

  • Can induce remission in many patients
  • May be used as pretreatment prior to radioactive iodine or thyroidectomy (eg, high-risk patient, severe hyperthyroidism)

Radioactive
iodine

  • Acceptable option for moderate hyperthyroidism
  • May initially worsen ophthalmopathy and hyperthyroid symptoms
  • Leads to permanent hypothyroidism over time

Thyroidectomy

  • Preferred in patients with very large goiter, obstructive symptoms, or ophthalmopathy

This patient has Graves disease (GD), presenting with primary hyperthyroidism (ie, elevated thyroid hormone levels, suppressed TSH), a diffuse goiter, and homogeneously increased radioiodine uptake.  Initial management of hyperthyroidism (from any cause) includes a beta blocker (eg, propranolol, atenolol) to control hyperadrenergic symptoms (eg, palpitation, tachycardia).

The hyperthyroid state in GD can be corrected with thionamide antithyroid drugs (ATDs) (eg, methimazole), radioactive iodine (RAI), or thyroidectomy.  In older patients (eg, age >65), especially those with cardiac comorbidities (eg, congestive heart failure, as in this patient), ATDs are favored for initial treatment because RAI can transiently worsen hyperthyroid symptoms and may be poorly tolerated (Choice A).  Once the patient returns to a euthyroid state, RAI can be considered, or the ATD may be continued for long-term management.

(Choice B)  Potassium iodide has a transient inhibitory effect on thyroid hormone synthesis and release.  It is used mainly in short courses (eg, 1-2 weeks) in preparation for thyroidectomy and for the treatment of thyroid storm but is not used when longer-term therapy is anticipated; thionamide ATDs are preferred.

(Choice C)  Systemic glucocorticoids (eg, prednisone) are used for thyroid storm, type 2 amiodarone-induced thyrotoxicosis, and severe cases of subacute (de Quervain) thyroiditis.

(Choice D)  Beta blockers alone are used for painless (silent) thyroiditis, which causes self-limited hyperthyroidism due to the release of preformed thyroid hormone.  However, GD is characterized by increased thyroid hormone synthesis, and an ATD is needed.

(Choice F)  Thyroidectomy is preferred for patients with large goiters causing obstructive symptoms and those with moderate or severe ophthalmopathy, which can worsen during RAI therapy.  However, it may not be preferred in older patients with increased surgical risk and would not be performed until the patient was in a euthyroid state on ATDs.

Educational objective:
Graves disease can be treated with thionamide antithyroid drugs, radioactive iodine, or thyroidectomy.  Antithyroid drugs are preferred for older patients and those with cardiac comorbidities (eg, heart failure) who may not tolerate surgery or the transient exacerbation of hyperthyroid symptoms from radioactive iodine.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Hyperthyroidism

answerChoiceList.choice: Begin prednisone with a slow taper
Observe and follow up in 6 weeks

questionList.questionText: A 16-year-old girl is brought to the clinic due to behavioral changes over the school year.  The patient has had difficulty concentrating, and her academic performance has declined.  She also has been uninterested in participating in her regular extracurricular activities or spending time with her boyfriend.  She sleeps approximately 9 hours a night, has no difficulty falling or staying asleep, and naps after school.  The patient typically eats 3 meals a day, but her appetite has recently decreased, which she attributes to intermittent constipation.  Medications include oral contraceptive pills.  Temperature is 37 C (98.6 F), blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg, pulse is 50/min, and respirations are 16/min.  BMI is at the 85th percentile.  The patient appears well, and the physical examination is unremarkable.  Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questionList.explanationText:
Clinical features of hypothyroidism

Mood symptoms

  • Depression
  • Apathy
  • Social withdrawal

Cognitive symptoms

  • Impaired concentration & memory
  • Psychomotor slowing
  • Executive dysfunction

Severe symptoms

  • Delirium
  • Psychosis (myxedema madness)

Physical symptoms

  • Bradycardia
  • Cold intolerance
  • Fatigue
  • Muscle weakness & myalgia
  • Hyporeflexia

This teenaged patient has difficulty concentrating as well as loss of interest in activities and relationships, symptoms that often suggest a mood disorder (eg, depression).  However, depressive symptoms are nonspecific and warrant a thorough history and physical examination to assess for an underlying medical condition (eg, hypothyroidism, vitamin B12 deficiency).  In this case, the patient also has constipation and bradycardia, raising concern for acquired hypothyroidism.

The most common cause of hypothyroidism in adolescents is autoimmune thyroiditis, in which immune-mediated thyroid gland destruction impairs thyroxine synthesis.  Hypothyroidism leads to a generalized hypometabolic state in children (similarly in adults), often marked by fatigue, constipation, bradycardia, and/or cold intolerance.  Mood and cognitive symptoms are common and in adolescents often include declining school performance, as seen here.  Features of hypothyroidism that are unique to children include declining growth velocity or short stature and delayed puberty.

Thyroid function tests show increased TSH and decreased free thyroxine levels, and most patients have elevated antithyroid antibodies (eg, antithyroglobulin, antithyroid peroxidase).  Treatment with levothyroxine typically results in improved depressive symptoms.

(Choice A)  Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (eg, fluoxetine) are first-line medications for depression and can be considered in an adolescent with typical manifestations (eg, difficulty concentrating, loss of interests) and an otherwise unrevealing history and physical examination.  However, the priority in this patient who also has bradycardia and constipation is evaluation for an underlying medical condition (ie, hypothyroidism).

(Choice B)  Oral contraceptive pills do not significantly affect mood and do not explain this patient's social withdrawal or difficulty concentrating, making medication discontinuation unnecessary.

(Choice C)  Sleep studies are indicated for fatigue and difficulty concentrating in the setting of snoring or frequent awakenings that are concerning for obstructive sleep apnea (OSA).  This patient sleeps 9 hours without difficulty falling or staying asleep.  In addition, bradycardia and constipation are not features of OSA.

(Choice E)  Stimulant medications are first-line agents for attention deficit hyperactivity disorder.  Although difficulty concentrating is common, symptoms are typically present before age 12, and this patient's new onset of symptoms, along with bradycardia, suggests a different cause.  In addition, standardized ratings from multiple sources (eg, parents, teachers) are typically obtained before initiating pharmacotherapy.

Educational objective:
Depressive symptoms (eg, declining school performance, loss of interest) may indicate an underlying medical condition, and acquired hypothyroidism should be considered in those who also have hypometabolic symptoms (eg, bradycardia, constipation).  Thyroid function tests show increased TSH and decreased free thyroxine levels.
questionList.subject: Pediatrics
questionList.title: Hypothyroidism

answerChoiceList.choice: Prescribe a trial of stimulant medication

questionList.questionText:
A 26-year-old woman comes to the office for a routine visit 6 months after the birth of her first child.  Her pregnancy and vaginal delivery were uneventful and her infant is healthy; she breastfed for the first 5 months.  The patient reports that during the first 2-3 months after childbirth she had excessive anxiety and worried frequently about her newborn daughter.  She also felt unusually fatigued and irritable, which has worsened over the last several weeks.  The patient has also experienced constipation, but her appetite is normal and she has gained 2.5 kg (5.5 lb) in the last 3 months.  Blood pressure is 130/90 mm Hg and pulse is 60/min.  Heart and lung sounds are normal.  Mild bilateral lower extremity edema is present.  Laboratory results are as follows:

Hemoglobin12 g/dL
Serum chemistry
    Sodium130 mEq/L
    Potassium4.2 mEq/L
    Creatinine1.1 mg/dL
    Glucose100 mg/dL
Total cholesterol280 mg/dL

Which of the following is the best next step in management of this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Thyroiditis

Clinical features

Diagnostic testing

Chronic autoimmune thyroiditis
(Hashimoto thyroiditis)

  • Predominant hypothyroid features
  • Diffuse goiter
  • Positive TPO antibody
  • Variable radioiodine uptake

Painless thyroiditis
(silent thyroiditis)

  • Variant of chronic autoimmune thyroiditis
  • Mild, brief hyperthyroid phase
  • Small, nontender goiter
  • Spontaneous recovery
  • Positive TPO antibody
  • Low radioiodine uptake

Subacute (granulomatous) thyroiditis
(de Quervain thyroiditis)

  • Likely postviral inflammatory process
  • Prominent fever & hyperthyroid symptoms
  • Painful/tender goiter
  • Elevated ESR & CRP
  • Low radioiodine uptake

CRP = C-reactive protein; ESR = erythrocyte sedimentation rate; TPO = thyroid peroxidase.

Postpartum thyroiditis occurs in 7%-8% of women after childbirth, usually in the first 6 months.  Patients can have a brief hyperthyroid phase due to release of preformed thyroid hormone but frequently have only mild, nonspecific symptoms (eg, anxiety [as seen in this patient], palpitations).  The subsequent hypothyroid phase (eg, fatigue, weight gain despite normal appetite, constipation) often brings patients to medical attention.  Examination typically shows a nontender goiter, bradycardia, diastolic hypertension, lower extremity edema, and other findings (eg, coarse facies, delayed deep tendon reflex relaxation).  In the hypothyroid phase, TSH will be elevated and free T4 levels will be low.  Other laboratory findings associated with hypothyroidism include hypercholesterolemia (due to thyroid effects on lipid metabolism) and hyponatremia.

Postpartum thyroiditis is similar to painless (silent) thyroiditis, but by convention the latter is not diagnosed within a year of childbirth.  Both may be considered variants of chronic lymphocytic (Hashimoto) thyroiditis and are associated with elevated titers of anti-thyroid peroxidase autoantibodies.  However, whereas Hashimoto thyroiditis frequently leads to permanent hypothyroidism, postpartum and painless thyroiditis are usually self-limited, and patients return to a euthyroid state over several months.

(Choice A)  Postpartum thyroiditis and postpartum depression cause overlapping symptoms.  Hypothyroidism should be excluded first as it is a reversible cause of depression.  In general, postpartum depression is more often associated with weight loss and additional depressive symptoms (eg, anhedonia, feelings of inappropriate guilt).  If thyroid function is normal, depression would be more likely.

(Choice B)  Peripartum cardiomyopathy is characterized by systolic heart failure and occurs in the last month of pregnancy or up to 5 months after delivery.  It can lead to edema and hyponatremia but would not occur 6 months after pregnancy and would present with respiratory features (eg, dyspnea, orthopnea, lung crackles) and tachycardia (rather than borderline bradycardia).  Hypothyroidism can cause lower extremity edema.

(Choice C)  Weight gain and hypercholesterolemia in postpartum hypothyroidism usually resolve with restoration of the euthyroid state.  Directed lifestyle and pharmacologic interventions are not usually needed.

(Choice D)  Hypothyroidism and adrenal insufficiency can both cause hyponatremia.  However, adrenal insufficiency is unlikely in this patient in light of the associated edema, weight gain, and normal blood pressure.

Educational objective:
Postpartum thyroiditis is an autoimmune disorder characterized by a possible brief hyperthyroid phase, a self-limited hypothyroid phase, and an ultimate return to a euthyroid state.  It is associated with anti-thyroid peroxidase autoantibodies.  Painless (silent) thyroiditis is a similar disorder, but by convention is not diagnosed within a year of childbirth.
questionList.subject: Obstetrics & Gynecology
questionList.title: Hypothyroidism

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Approach to the patient with postpartum thyroiditis.

questionList.questionText:
A 37-year-old woman comes to the office with a 7-month history of galactorrhea and amenorrhea.  She has also had worsening vaginal dryness, but no headaches or visual symptoms.  The patient's medical history is unremarkable, and she does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs.  She is married, has 2 children, and remarks that her family is "complete."  The patient's husband has undergone vasectomy.  Her temperature is 36.7 C (98 F), blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg, pulse is 72/min, and respirations are 14/min.  Visual field testing is normal.  Pregnancy test is negative, serum prolactin level is 150 ng/mL (154 ng/mL on repeat measurement), and thyrotropin (TSH) and serum creatinine are normal.  MRI of the pituitary gland reveals a 6-mm hypointense lesion, as shown in the image below, which is consistent with a pituitary adenoma.

Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
This patient has a pituitary microadenoma (<10 mm) associated with galactorrhea and symptoms of low estrogen (eg, amenorrhea, vaginal dryness).  Any mass lesion in the pituitary gland can cause a mild elevation in prolactin due to disruption of the normal inhibitory dopaminergic regulation of prolactin secretion.  However, significant elevations in the prolactin level (eg, serum prolactin level >200 ng/mL or repeat level >100 ng/mL) suggest a prolactin-secreting tumor (prolactinoma).  Elevated prolactin levels suppress gonadotropin-releasing hormone, LH, and estradiol, leading to oligo-amenorrhea in premenopausal females.  Men and postmenopausal women often have minimal early symptoms and are more likely to seek evaluation when a large tumor (>1 cm, macroadenoma) causes mass-effect symptoms (eg, headache, visual field defects).

Asymptomatic patients with an incidental finding of a microprolactinoma may be observed over time (Choice A).  Patients with macroprolactinomas or symptomatic tumors of any size (as with this patient) should be treated with dopaminergic agonists (eg, cabergoline, bromocriptine), which can normalize prolactin levels and reduce tumor size.  Patients who fail to respond or who have very large tumors (>3 cm) should be referred for transsphenoidal resection (Choice C).

(Choice B)  Patients with residual prolactinoma tissue following resection can be considered for radiotherapy.  However, the response to radiotherapy is generally delayed, and radiotherapy may lead to panhypopituitarism.

(Choice E)  Estrogen replacement therapy may be given to reduce the risk of osteoporosis in hypoestrogenic women with microprolactinoma who do not tolerate dopamine agonists.  However, estrogen does not reduce tumor size.

Educational objective:
Patients with a macroprolactinoma (>1 cm) or a symptomatic prolactinoma should be treated with dopaminergic agonists (eg, cabergoline, bromocriptine), which can lower prolactin levels and reduce tumor size.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Hyperprolactinemia

answerChoiceList.choice: Monitoring by periodic serum prolactin and MRI

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Diagnosis and treatment of hyperprolactinemia: An Endocrine Society clinical practice guideline.

questionList.questionText: A 26-year-old woman calls the office with a question about management of hypothyroidism during pregnancy.  The patient is not pregnant but wishes to become pregnant soon.  She has a history of hypothyroidism for several years and has been on a stable dose of levothyroxine.  TSH checked 3 months ago was 2.0 µU/mL.  The patient currently has mild fatigue but is otherwise asymptomatic.  Family history is notable for primary hypothyroidism in her mother, who is doing well on a regimen of liothyronine (T3) and levothyroxine (T4).  Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation for this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Maternal thyroid testing in pregnancy, 1st trimester

Hormone

Change

Mechanism

Total T4

Increased

  • β-hCG stimulates thyroid hormone production in 1st trimester
  • Estrogen stimulates TBG; thyroid increases hormone production to maintain steady free T4 level

Free T4

Unchanged or mildly increased

TSH

Decreased

  • Increased β-hCG & thyroid hormone suppress TSH secretion

TBG = thyroxine-binding globulin.

During pregnancy, estrogen induces an increase in serum thyroxine-binding globulin levels, requiring an increase in the amount of thyroid hormone needed to saturate the binding sites.  Thyroxine production is also increased due to the stimulatory effects of hCG on TSH receptors (as hCG and TSH have a similar alpha subunit).  These changes lead to an increase in total thyroid hormone levels, with a minimal increase in free hormone levels and a decrease in TSH.  However, patients with pre-existing hypothyroidism are unable to increase thyroxine production appropriately and are at risk for a worsening hypothyroid state and adverse fetal and maternal effects (eg, gestational hypertension, preeclampsia, premature delivery, postpartum hemorrhage).

Individuals such as this patient on a stable dose of thyroid replacement should have their dose increased by approximately 30% at the time the pregnancy is detected (Choices A and B).  The dose should be adjusted subsequently (typically in 4-week increments) based on TSH using pregnancy-specific norms.  Total T4 should also be followed and maintained within pregnancy-specific norms.

(Choice C)  This patient has been on a stable dose of levothyroxine and has a TSH in the low-normal range (<2.5 µU/mL).  She does not require dosing adjustments at this time.

(Choice E)  T3 is the active form of thyroid hormone and is produced predominantly by conversion from T4 in peripheral tissues.  However, T3 has a short half-life, and supplementation with liothyronine (oral T3) is associated with wide fluctuations in blood levels.  T3 supplementation is not recommended for most patients with primary hypothyroidism, and those who are taking T3 should be changed to levothyroxine alone if considering pregnancy.

Educational objective:
Levothyroxine requirements increase during pregnancy.  Patients with hypothyroidism should increase their levothyroxine dose at the time pregnancy is detected, with subsequent dose adjustments based on TSH and total T4 using pregnancy-specific norms.
questionList.subject: Obstetrics & Gynecology
questionList.title: Hypothyroidism

answerChoiceList.choice: Continue the current levothyroxine dose through pregnancy
Decrease the levothyroxine dose when the patient becomes pregnant
Increase the levothyroxine dose prior to pregnancy
Increase the levothyroxine dose when the patient becomes pregnant
Switch to combination treatment with liothyronine and levothyroxine

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Management of thyroid dysfunction during pregnancy and postpartum: an Endocrine Society clinical practice guideline.

questionList.questionText: A 4-month-old girl is brought to the clinic for a well-child check.  The mother is concerned that the girl is less active than other children at day care.  The patient is exclusively formula-fed and must be awakened for most feeds; she has also been having less frequent bowel movements for the past month.  She was born to a 30-year-old woman at term via spontaneous vaginal delivery at home.  The mother is healthy but had limited prenatal care.  Height and weight were at the 50th percentile at birth; weight is at the 25th percentile today.  The patient is afebrile with mild bradycardia.  The anterior and posterior fontanelles are enlarged, and the patient has a large, protruding tongue without fasciculations.  The abdomen is protuberant with a large, reducible umbilical hernia.  She is unable to lift her head when prone.  Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's presentation?
questionList.explanationText:
Congenital hypothyroidism

Pathophysiology

  • Thyroid dysgenesis most common (eg, agenesis, hypoplasia, ectopy)

Clinical
manifestations

  • Asymptomatic at birth*
  • Symptomatic weeks to months after birth (as maternal T4 wanes)
    • Hypometabolism: ↓ HR & temperature, lethargy/poor feeding, hypotonia, constipation, jaundice
    • Mucopolysaccharide accumulation: macroglossia, umbilical hernia
    • Delayed bone maturation: enlarged fontanelles

Diagnosis

  • Newborn screening
  • ↑ TSH & ↓ T4

Treatment

  • Levothyroxine

Prognosis

  • No deficits if treatment started in neonatal period
  • Untreated disease leads to intellectual disability, developmental delay & poor growth

*Can rarely present with delayed passage of meconium.

HR = heart rate.

This 4-month-old patient who is unable to lift her head has hypotonia, a worrisome finding in young infants that may be suggestive of a neuromuscular or genetic disorder but is more commonly due to an infectious or metabolic condition.  This patient also has bradycardia, enlarged fontanelles, and constipation, characteristic findings of congenital hypothyroidism.  Patients are typically asymptomatic at birth due to the transplacental transfer of maternal T4, and they develop symptoms as levels wane over weeks to months.

Congenital hypothyroidism is usually due to thyroid dysgenesis and leads to a hypometabolic state characterized by lethargy (eg, less activity, feeding problems/poor weight gain), constipation, and bradycardia, as in this patient.  Because skeletal muscle is a highly metabolic tissue that requires thyroid hormone signaling for contractile functioning, patients develop diffuse myopathy with hypotonia and weakness.  T4 also regulates the degradation of mucopolysaccharides, which accumulate in subcutaneous tissue in hypothyroidism, causing myxedematous skin changes (eg, macroglossia, protuberant abdomen, umbilical hernia).  Finally, enlarged fontanelles with delayed closure are typical because thyroid hormone promotes bone growth and maturation.

Laboratory evaluation shows increased TSH and decreased T4.  Prompt treatment with levothyroxine reduces the risk for neurologic deficits and developmental delay.

(Choice A)  Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome is an overgrowth disorder often associated with macroglossia and umbilical hernia.  Unlike in this patient, hypotonia is not seen, and macrosomia (weight >97th percentile) would be expected.

(Choice C)  Congenital myotonic dystrophy causes severe hypotonia and weakness.  However, symptoms are present at birth, not beginning at age 4 months.  Patients typically require mechanical ventilation in the neonatal period due to respiratory failure.

(Choice D)  Infant botulism most commonly occurs due to the ingestion of environmental Clostridium botulinum spores.  Patients have hypotonia with constipation, poor feeding, and autonomic signs (eg, fluctuating heart rate).  In contrast to the symptoms in this patient, however, symptoms in infant botulism progress rapidly (<1 week) to bulbar weakness and respiratory compromise.

(Choice E)  Spinal muscular atrophy type I is characterized by progressive hypotonia and symmetric paralysis, and bulbar muscle involvement typically leads to poor feeding and growth.  However, tongue fasciculations are a classic finding and are not seen in this patient whose enlarged fontanelles and bradycardia would not be expected in spinal muscular atrophy type I.

Educational objective:
Hypotonia in young infants should raise concern for congenital hypothyroidism in the setting of hypometabolic symptoms (eg, constipation, bradycardia, poor feeding/weight gain), as well as enlarged fontanelles and macroglossia.
questionList.subject: Pediatrics
questionList.title: Hypothyroidism

questionList.questionText:
A 35-year-old man comes to the office due to a 2-day history of jitteriness, chills, and malaise.  The patient has also had anterior neck pain that radiates to his jaw and ears.  He recovered from an upper respiratory tract illness a week before the onset of his current symptoms but previously had felt well.  The patient was seen in the clinic occasionally in the remote past for sexually transmitted infections, but his medical history is otherwise unremarkable.  He lives alone and is sexually active with both men and women.  Temperature is 38 C (100.4 F), blood pressure is 150/70 mm Hg, and pulse is 110/min.  The thyroid gland is diffusely enlarged and tender.  Laboratory results are as follows:

Complete blood count
Hemoglobin13.9 g/dL
Hematocrit44%
Platelets200,000/mm3
Leukocytes10,500/mm3
TSH<0.001 µU/mL
Free T44.6 ng/dL (normal: 0.9-2.4)
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate100 mm/hr

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Thyroiditis

Clinical features

Diagnostic testing

Chronic autoimmune thyroiditis
(Hashimoto thyroiditis)

  • Predominant hypothyroid features
  • Diffuse goiter
  • Positive TPO antibody
  • Variable radioiodine uptake

Painless thyroiditis
(silent thyroiditis)

  • Variant of chronic autoimmune thyroiditis
  • Mild, brief hyperthyroid phase
  • Small, nontender goiter
  • Spontaneous recovery
  • Positive TPO antibody
  • Low radioiodine uptake

Subacute thyroiditis
(de Quervain thyroiditis)

  • Neck pain with painful/tender goiter
  • Transient hyperthyroid phase
  • Often follows viral upper respiratory tract infection
  • Elevated ESR & CRP
  • Low radioiodine uptake

CRP = C-reactive protein; ESR = erythrocyte sedimentation rate; TPO = thyroid peroxidase.

This patient has subacute thyroiditis presenting with primary hyperthyroidism (elevated free T4, suppressed TSH), low-grade fever, and a painful, tender goiter.  Subacute (de Quervain, subacute granulomatous) thyroiditis is thought to be due to a postviral inflammatory process and is often preceded by an upper respiratory tract illness.  The diagnosis is based primarily on clinical features; additional supportive findings include elevated inflammatory markers (eg, erythrocyte sedimentation rate, C-reactive protein) and low radioiodine uptake (because the hyperthyroidism is due to release of preformed thyroid hormone rather than new hormone synthesis).

Thyrotoxicosis in subacute thyroiditis resolves spontaneously within a few weeks and may be followed by a hypothyroid phase lasting a few months.  Most patients eventually recover to a euthyroid state.  Treatment includes beta blockers to control thyrotoxic symptoms and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) for pain relief.  Glucocorticoids are used for severe thyroid pain not responding to NSAIDs.

(Choices A, B, and E)  Acute HIV infection can cause fever, pharyngitis, and lymphadenopathy, often with a generalized rash and gastrointestinal symptoms (ie, antiretroviral syndrome).  Acute gonococcal infection also can present with pharyngitis and fever.  Retropharyngeal space infections in adults commonly present as neck pain and fever, often with dysphagia.  However, none of these disorders is associated with a goiter or hyperthyroid state.

(Choices C and D)  Graves disease typically presents with thyrotoxicosis and goiter, often with proptosis.  Chronic lymphocytic (Hashimoto) thyroiditis typically presents with hypothyroidism, although patients may develop a brief hyperthyroid phase.  However, the goiter seen in both of these conditions is nontender, and fever is uncommon.

(Choice G)  Suppurative infection of the thyroid gland (infectious thyroiditis) is a rare condition that most commonly occurs in children.  It presents with high-grade fever and pain at the thyroid gland, which may be palpably enlarged due to abscess formation.  However, the pain is typically unilateral, and patients are usually euthyroid due to focal (rather than diffuse) thyroid involvement.

Educational objective:
Subacute (de Quervain) thyroiditis is characterized by fever, neck pain, and a tender goiter following an upper respiratory tract illness.  Patients have a self-limited thyrotoxic phase followed by hypothyroidism and eventual recovery of thyroid function.  Treatment is directed at symptom relief and includes beta blockers and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Hyperthyroidism

questionList.questionText:
A 30-year-old man comes to the office for a preventive medical evaluation.  The patient has not seen a physician for many years and has no prior significant medical conditions.  He has gained 4.5 kg (9.9 lb) over the past year despite exercising regularly and having a healthy diet.  The patient does not smoke and has moderate alcohol intake.  Blood pressure is 130/92 mm Hg and pulse is 60/min.  BMI is 24 kg/m2.  Physical examination is normal.  Fasting serum lipid results are as follows:

Total cholesterol280 mg/dL
HDL40 mg/dL
LDL180 mg/dL
Triglycerides300 mg/dL

Which of the following is the best next step in management of this patient's dyslipidemia?
questionList.explanationText:
Indications to test for hypothyroidism in asymptomatic patients

Clinical findings
& history

  • Bradycardia, diastolic hypertension
  • Pleural/pericardial effusion
  • Autoimmune disease (eg, vitiligo, type 1 diabetes mellitus)

Laboratory
abnormalities

  • Hyperlipidemia
  • Hyponatremia
  • Macrocytic anemia
  • Hyperprolactinemia

Pituitary/hypothalamic
disorders

  • Sellar/parasellar mass
  • Pituitary surgery or radiation
  • Acute or chronic hypopituitarism

This young patient has dyslipidemia (eg, high triglycerides and LDL) despite maintaining a healthy weight and lifestyle.  Given his associated constitutional symptoms (eg, weight gain), he should be tested for hypothyroidism with a serum TSH level.  Hypothyroidism causes decreased LDL clearance largely due to decreased expression and activity of hepatic LDL receptors and is associated with elevated total cholesterol and LDL levels and increased risk for coronary artery disease.  It also causes decreased activity of lipoprotein lipase, leading to hypertriglyceridemia.

In patients with hypothyroidism-associated dyslipidemia, treatment with levothyroxine often improves lipid levels and may obviate the need for specific lipid-lowering therapy, especially in young, low-risk patients.  If not already checked, TSH levels should also be considered prior to the initiation of statin medications (eg, atorvastatin) because untreated hypothyroidism can increase the risk for statin myopathy (Choice A).

(Choice B)  Anabolic steroid use is associated with elevated total cholesterol and LDL and decreased HDL.  It is not associated with hypertriglyceridemia.

(Choices D and E)  Adding ezetimibe to a statin may lower the risk for cardiovascular events in patients with established atherosclerosis; benefits in primary prevention are less clear.  Fibrates (eg, gemfibrozil) can reduce the risk for pancreatitis due to very high triglyceride levels (eg, >1,000 mg/dL), but lifestyle interventions are preferred as initial therapy for mild hypertriglyceridemia.

(Choice F)  LDL receptor mutations are seen in some patients with familial hypercholesterolemia.  This disorder is characterized by LDL levels of >190 mg/dL, often with cutaneous xanthomas and a strong family history of premature atherosclerosis, findings not seen in this patient.

Educational objective:
Hypothyroidism can cause elevated levels of total cholesterol, LDL, and triglycerides and is associated with an increased risk for coronary atherosclerosis.  Treatment with levothyroxine can improve lipid levels.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Hypothyroidism

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Direct effects of thyroid hormones on hepatic lipid metabolism.
The lipid-lowering effect of levothyroxine in patients with subclinical hypothyroidism: a systematic review and meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials.

questionList.questionText:
A 24-year-old primigravida comes to the office for her first prenatal visit.  Her last menstrual period was 8 weeks ago and 2 home pregnancy tests have been positive.  The patient feels generally well, although she has experienced mild intermittent nausea and anxiety during the pregnancy.  Medical history is unremarkable, and her only medication is an over-the-counter prenatal vitamin.  Thyroid function tests were normal on evaluation for fatigue and mild palpitations 6 months ago.  The patient stopped drinking alcohol after finding out she was pregnant, and she does not use tobacco or illicit drugs.  Blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg and pulse is 82/min.  Physical examination findings are normal.  Pelvic ultrasound shows a gestational sac containing a fetal pole and a yolk sac.  Thyroid function study results are as follows:

TodaySix months ago
TSH0.3 µU/mL2.0 µU/mL
Total thyroxine (T4)15 µg/dL8 µg/dL
Total triiodothyronine (T3)220 ng/dL130 ng/dL

Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's current laboratory findings?
questionList.explanationText:
Maternal thyroid testing in pregnancy, 1st trimester

Hormone

Change

Mechanism

Total T4

Increased

  • β-hCG stimulates thyroid hormone production in 1st trimester
  • Estrogen stimulates TBG; thyroid increases hormone production to maintain steady free T4 level

Free T4

Unchanged or mildly increased

TSH

Decreased

  • Increased β-hCG & thyroid hormone suppress TSH secretion

TBG = thyroxine-binding globulin.

Thyroid hormone production increases during pregnancy to cope with metabolic demands.  This is accomplished by 2 mechanisms:

  • Estrogen stimulates synthesis of thyroxine-binding globulin (TBG) and decreases TBG clearance, leading to an increased pool of bound thyroid hormone.  Patients with normal thyroid reserve subsequently increase thyroid hormone production to maintain free hormone levels.
  • hCG (which shares a common alpha subunit with TSH and a very similar beta subunit) directly stimulates TSH receptors.  This results in increased hormone production with feedback suppression of pituitary TSH release.

In patients with normal thyroid function, the net effect (as seen in this patient) can resemble subclinical hyperthyroidism with increased circulating total T3 and T4, normal (or mildly elevated) free T4, and suppressed TSH, although the patient remains clinically euthyroid.  However, patients with impaired thyroid function (eg, chronic lymphocytic [Hashimoto] thyroiditis) cannot increase thyroid hormone production, resulting in a relative hypothyroid state (Choice C).  For this reason, patients with baseline hypothyroidism who become pregnant should have their replacement thyroxine dose increased.

(Choice A)  Euthyroid sick syndrome is an alteration in biochemical thyroid function tests in the setting of severe nonthyroid illness.  Common findings include a low total and free T3 with a normal T4 and TSH.

(Choice B)  Graves disease causes an increase in total and free thyroid hormone levels.  However, most patients will have additional manifestations, such as proptosis, diffuse goiter, hypertension, and tachycardia.

(Choice D)  Iodine requirements increase during pregnancy, and inadequate iodine intake can cause maternal and fetal hypothyroidism.  Such patients would have an elevated TSH with decreased thyroid hormone levels.

(Choice F)  Subacute (granulomatous or De Quervain) thyroiditis can cause hyperthyroidism with a suppressed TSH.  However, it most commonly follows an acute viral illness and is associated with a painful, tender goiter.

Educational objective:
Thyroid hormone production increases during pregnancy to cope with metabolic demands.  Estrogen causes an increase in thyroxine-binding globulin, leading to increased total (but not free) thyroid hormone levels.  hCG directly stimulates TSH receptors, causing increased production of thyroid hormones.
